Drinking tea for the health benefits is like reading Playboy for the articles: you're either lying, or you're missing the whole point.

My first teapot was one like this, that I thought looked really cool. And it got me into tea, and was fine. Then, as I learned more, I found that it kept the water at too hot a temperature for optimal steeping. You definitely want a mesh infuser like that - easy to wash.
Here's a cheaper but much higher quality teapot from one of the best online tea merchants, [Upton Tea](http://uptontea.com/shopcart/item.asp?from=catalog.asp itemID=AP22 begin=0 parent=Accessories%3ETeaware%3ETeapots category=Chatsford sortMethod=0 categoryID=88).
And they are actually a local company (although they've moved from Upton to Hopkinton). They have great service, a wide selection, and they let you order a small sample of even their priciest teas.

WRITING.TEXT:
I know this is distressing, but be careful not to blow it out of proportion. Maybe my perspective is skewed because, from the day they were born, my father has shown no real interest in his twin grandchildren (other writing them generous birthday checks). It took him until they were older than 2 to even tell them apart (mind you, these are boy-girl twins and we tended to keep them in gender-specific clothing).
So be glad that your mother-in-law cares for at least one.

WRITING.TEXT: You can buy the actual power generation from a couple of other companies, but you won't save much money, and NSTAR will still be the one delivering the power to your plugs and billing you. NSTAR does have a 'green' option where you pay extra and all your power comes from renewable resources (or pay a bit less extra and 50% of your power is renewable).

WRITING.TEXT: The nature of statistics is that the larger the number, the more accurate they are. This is why a medical study is done on thousands of people - because if, for instance, a drug cures one person, it doesn't mean much. Similarly, you have this one weird data point. If it were 1 of 10 users, it wouldn't stand out as much.
I would still wait for Paul to show up.
There's always some margin of error and strangeness in analytics. The numbers don't add up to 100%. Bots do strange things. I wouldn't put much stock in one visitor.

Yes, you're good until the age where the birthday honorees start keeping track. At age 4, the kids are just excited with a present, and it's really the parents who you're impressing. And if they're the type of parent who's keeping track of "I invited three children but my darling only got one present", then they're probably not the type of parent you want to associate with.

I've ordered from Target.com, so they know lots of PII about me, and I've read in [Charles Duhigg's book](http://www.target.com/p/the-power-of-habit-unabridged-compact-disc/-/A-13862584) that they match up that with my in-store shopping habits. Do they (and companies like them) sell that information on to Acxiom and other companies? Or could it get matched up with an Ad Network cookie to build an even larger profile on me?
Thanks. Have to admit I signed up 6 years ago, then forgot about it for five ;)

Make sure that each has some toys that are his or her own, and some of which there are two identical copies, so that they don't feel like they have to fight over everything. Hopefully, if they have some sense of mastery over some toys, they won't feel as driven to fight over all toys.
This worked a little with us.

Worth noting: first kid is a life-changer for everyone, and you'd be freaking out some even if you were just having a singleton.
It's good that you're being realistic about how hard it will be. The first couple of years are not pretty. But (and I hated when people told me this when mine were young) it does get easier.
As to strollers, many of those strollers that get out-grown after a year get sold used after a year. Don't feel you need to get everything new - your kids really won't be able to tell the difference.

Yes, NYC has a lot more international service and competition than Boston. And it's only a $20-30 bus ride away from Boston.
Also, try and create some links to the home page that Google can follow - for instance, +1 it, share it on Facebook, start other link building campaigns.

When I was a kid in the 70s, when you drove on 95 and hit 128, there were big signs that said: Interstate Ends. At some point, the highway bureaucrats decided that they weren't going to build the highway through the center of the city, and at that point they made 95 continuous along 128.
